A few suggestions that I think would improve JIRA from a general project management perspective (and I think they are probably easy to implement to boot).

1.  A 'estimated close date' or 'due date' field for issues (I think this may already be on the list).  Would allow for some basic over/under schedule type metrics.

2.  'target date' and 'release date' tracking on versions (again simple scheduling metrics).

3.  It would be very useful to be able to attach documents to the project itself, not only to issues.  Often a project has high level documents (project charter, licensing docs, coding conventions, etc) that need to be in a highly visible, easily accessible location.  Creating bogus issues to attach then to doesn't work so well (out of sight, out of mind).  It would be great to be able to attach them directly to a project and have them listed on the main project detail screen.

Thanks,

Joe
fields.summary: Project management improvements

{panel:title=Atlassian Update – 31 December 2015|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#ebf2f9 | titleBGColor=#ebf2f9 | bgColor=#ffffff}
Hi everyone,

Thanks for voting and commenting on this issue. Your feedback is key to helping us understand how you use JIRA so we can continue improving your experience. We have reviewed this issue over the last few days; however there are not currently any plans to implement this suggestion.

While we absolutely understand many the logic behind many of the requests for subcomponents, we strongly believe that our focus should be on making JIRA simpler and easier to use. Simply put, additional levels of hierarchy for components is likely to add complexity on a conceptual level, at a technical level (more bugs and slower performance) and will lead to a more confusing UI.

There are several add-ons available on the Marketplace addressing the requirements outlined below:
* [Subcomponents for JIRA Cloud|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/net.brokenbuild.cloud.subcomponents/cloud/overview]
* [Component/Subcomponent/Bundle Versions|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/com.deniz.jira.versioning/server/reviews] (for JIRA Server)
* [Subcomponents for JIRA|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/net.brokenbuild.subcomponents] (for JIRA Server)

Please remember that jira.atlassian.com is one of many inputs for the JIRA roadmap. You can [learn more about our process here|https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/110373/how-does-the-jira-team-use-jira-atlassian-com].
 
I understand that our decision may be disappointing. Please don't hesitate to contact me if you have any questions.
 
Regards,
Dave Meyer

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-690].
  {panel}

Email Confirmation
-------------------
Why:

1. To discourage nasties from registering as a third person [who is not himself]
2. To discourage frivilous use of issue submittal. (This assumes that a user will be more inclined to create "good" issues if he knows his identity is known.)
3. To satisfy corporate edicts. (Fortunately, I am not under any editcs :-)

How:

1. User enters registration information (just like now)
2. Jira creates a user object in the database in an "unconfirmed" state with an associated "confirmation code".
3. Jira notfies the user that an email has been sent containing a confirmation code/link. Jira sends the email to the user.
4. User receives confirmation email, clicks on confirmation link. 
5. Jira servlet at url specified in email receives confirmation code, and "confirms" user registration.
6. User can now login in to Jira

4a. User receives email, but was not the one who registered.
4b. User optionally contacts Jira admin, who can, if required, attempt to track down the perpitrator.

Admin Confirmation
-------------------
Why:

1. To ensure that only customers can view issues. (This is much less a priority, as groups can be used to provide access control to projects.)

How:

1. User enters registration information (just like now)
2. Jira creates a user object in the database in an "unapproved" state.
3. Jira notfies the user that an email will be sent once his registration has been approved. 
4. Jira sends the email to admin and/or provides list of registrations required via an admin page.
5. Admin approves via email or admin page.
6. Jira changes user registration to "approved" state and sends email notice to user.
6. User can now login in to Jira

5a. Admin does not approve registration, and specifies a reason.
5b. Jira sends "too bad" email to user
fields.summary: Registration that requires email response and/or admin response

Hi,

Not sure if this is outside the scope of the project but here's an idea.  We now have the perfect issue-resolution work flow with Jira, where users report an issue, we resolve it, then they close it once they've tested the resolution.  (Just to clarify, our 'users' give us a spec for the applications that we develop and so are internal, not Joe Public...)

It would be a great extension of this workflow to apply it to versions of projects as well as to individual bugs.  This would mean that our users can 'sign-off' a version as being complete and ready for deployment to production.

Would anyone else find this useful?  Currently we do all our great work in Jira then have to go to Lotus Notes for sign-off (!)  Linking to Jira's roadmap of course ;)  Which almost works...! (JRA-633)

  Mike

fields.description:
When creating an issue in Advanced Roadmaps and populating *Target start* and *Target end* date fields, the stored dates fetched through the REST API are not all correct.

For instance, when you create an Epic and set:
 * *Due Date* (System Field)
 * *Target start* (ARJ field)
 * *Target end* (ARJ field); and
 * *myCustomDateField* (custom Date picker field)

to today (2021/12/21), the issue view shows:
{noformat}
Due Date:	21/Dec/21
Target start:	21/Dec/21
Target end:	21/Dec/21
myCustomDateField:	21/Dec/21{noformat}
 

When using a *-0300 TZ* for Jira{{{}, the *rest/api/latest/issue/BS-5*{}}} shows:
{noformat}
duedate: "2021-12-21",
customfield_10101: "2021-12-20", --Target start
customfield_10102: "2021-12-20", --Target end
customfield_10300: "2021-12-21", --myCustomDateField
{noformat}
 

When the Jira system TZ is changed to {*}UTC +1{*}, the dates are all correct:
{noformat}
duedate: "2021-12-21",
customfield_10101: "2021-12-21", --Target start
customfield_10102: "2021-12-21", --Target end
customfield_10300: "2021-12-21", --myCustomDateField{noformat}
fields.summary: Target start and target end dates are not properly reflecting the dates when using any "negative" timezone in relation to UTC

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

Currently, Advanced Roadmaps capacity distribution does not take into consideration updates made to the capacity of a team for a particular iteration or sprint and distribute the work to the rest of sprints/iterations. Having this ability would help in better planning, consider a situation where an iteration's capacity needs to be adjusted, for example when a developer is on leave, capacity distribution should consider this change and distribute the work accordingly to the rest of the iterations.

Below are the screenshots showing current behaviour.

*Image #1* Showing capacity distribution with each iteration having the same capacity
!orig_capcatiy_distribution.png|width=500,height=150!

*Image #2* Showing capacity distribution with a capacity of one of the iteration set to zero, we can see that it still has 20h of work assigned to the iteration.
!capacity_distribution_after_change.png|width=500,height=150!
h3. Suggested Solution

Advanced Roadmaps Capacity distribution should honor changes made to the capacity of individual iteration and dynamically distribute the work-based to rest of the iterations to help planning work in an agile environment.
fields.summary: Advanced Roadmaps capacity distribution should honour changes made to the capacity of a team for a particular iteration/sprint and distribute work accordingly.

fields.description:
As a product owner, I would like to view my advanced roadmap as: 
 * Group by: Sprint
 * Sort by: Sprint 

Ideally, I would like to show the total capacity for all teams added together, rather than individual capacity for each team.

*+{color:#FF0000}Use case:{color}+* When reviewing past sprints, it would be helpful to see the total capacity for all teams combined to get a high-level look at my overall team's workload. 

{color:#FF0000}+*Benefit:*+{color} I can quickly check the overall progress of all teams, then dive into individual teams for additional details. 

For example, instead of having all teams broken up, I would like the option to view a combined look at all teams.

!image-2021-12-20-13-03-10-319.png!
fields.summary: View Settings

fields.description:
{color:#FF0000}+*Use case:*+ {color}As a product owner, I would like not only to be able to plan future sprints within Jira Cloud, but also to review past sprints as well. This will allow my team to easily plan and review sprint progress all in one place. 

{color:#FF0000}*+Benefit:+* {color}Currently, my team needs to switch between the velocity report (which only shows seven sprints anyway), the project itself, and advanced roadmaps to plan and review sprints. Adding the initial commitment and completed points/issues here would save a lot of time and provide some much-needed context to sprint planning meetings.

I envision it would go here: 

!image-2021-12-20-12-54-11-874.png!
fields.summary: Add commitment and completed points to Jira Advanced Roadmaps

fields.description:
Dear team,

As an Advanced Roadmaps Plan user, I would like to be able to automatically shift the start dates and end dates of all issues that are dependant on a particular issue, if the end that of that issue changes.

Example: There is a blocker bug that blocks start of several stories, and their dependants (testing, documentation, etc.). The expected end date of the bug fix has moved by several days, which means the stories won't be able to start on the expected start date, nor the issues dependent on them, and so one - dozens of work items need to have their dates shifted.

I would like to be able to auto-shift all the dates (both start end end) of all the issues based on the changes on end dates (or start dates, if using consecutive start of dependencies) - there could possibly be a confirmation step, e.g. "Would you like to shift all dependent issues accordingly, by X days?".

This requirement has come up repeatedly from many Plans users in our organization, since this is something they are able to do in MS Project easily. It was a blocker for some of them to switch to planning their projects in Jira from MS Project.

Thanks,
Daniel
fields.summary: Automatically shift dates of dependent issues based on blocker end date change

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

After disabling warnings in a plan, Roadmap still shows the warnings in a plan when a user refreshes a plan.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a test Roadmap plan.
# Create some issues in the plan.
# Configure the issues in the plan with either "Target date" beyond "Due date" or set the "Target End Date" to an earlier date than the current date. 
# Enable the warnings in the plan and this should allow the plan to display yellow exclamation marks beside the affected issues.
# Turn off the warnings in the plan.
# Refresh the plan.

*  [^PSSRV-26930.webm] 

h3. Expected Results

Roadmap does not display the warnings since it's disabled.

h3. Actual Results

Roadmap still displays the warnings even after it's disabled.

h3. Workaround

None. Users need to toggle the warning again to remove the warnings from the plan.
fields.summary: Roadmap does not remove warning after warnings are disabled

fields.description:
h3. Problem definition:

In the Advance Roadmaps adding a field 'Resolution' is not possible.
h3. Suggested Solution:

Allow adding the 'Resolution' field to the Advanced Roadmaps.
h3. Why is this important:

Providing a visual representation of the issues that need to be done or not.
h3. Workaround:

Created a custom field (text field) to act as the resolution field.

Copy the value of the resolution field to the custom field via automation (or even workflow post function).

Add the custom field to the plan as a substitute.
fields.summary: Adding a Resolution field to Advanced Roadmaps

fields.description:
h4. Summary
Even when the date picker custom field context is configured for projects and issue types that are retrieved by the Plan's issue source, the date picker custom field is still greyed out and cannot be selected. 

According to our documentation, for the field to be available it needs to be:
* In the scope of all projects in a plan (technically - all projects from all issue sources (including filters) in a plan)
* In the scope of all issue types in a plan
* Be the custom field type of date picker (in the DB it's "com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.customfieldtypes:datepicker")

h4. Steps to reproduce
# Create a project, with a few issue types (let's say; bug, epic, story).
# Create a date picker custom field.
#* Set context to the above project for the bug, epic, story issue types.
# Go to plan > configure > scheduling

h4. Expected result
The date picker custom field can be selected for the plan's scheduling.

h4. Actual result
The date picker custom field appears greyed out and cannot be selected for the plan's scheduling.

h4. Workaround
# Set the custom field context to global context, or
# Set the custom field to the project retrieved by the Plan's issue source, but for all issue types
fields.summary: Date picker custom field cannot be selected in Plan's scheduling

fields.description: In active sprint and backlog, users can define quick filters leveraging arbitrary JQL. For example, we define quick filters on components. However, roadmap only has filters based on status, label, and type. Thus, we cannot apply the same filter mechanisms we use in backlog to roadmap view
fields.summary: Make quick filters available for roadmap

fields.description:
Apologies for posting this here, but there is no project for Jira Align, nor do I see any way to ask for an enhancement for that product. 

I'm looking for a way to associate enablers to multiple business features.  There's more information in my community post linked below, but essentially, to aid with prioritization and roadmaps, it would be extremely helpful if we could visualize which enablers support which business features.  This way, we could easily prioritize the enablers that support our most valuable features, and when we forecast their completion on the roadmap, we could select the business feature and the enablers would be included in the roadmap with it. 

 

 

https://community.atlassian.com/t5/Jira-Align-questions/Is-there-a-way-to-visualize-the-relationship-between-enablers/qaq-p/1863381#M2037
fields.summary: Suggestion for Jira Align

fields.description:
The Road Map timeline is a visual tool. When looking at a long-range plan it takes mental energy to keep scanning back up to the dates. To aid in the quick understanding of the timeline, it would be helpful to have visual aids in the date headings of a new year. This would include a vertical line through the timeline, and the year as a separate text element.

There is a proposal attached for calling out a year. It may be worth considering a similar option when a month changes if the view is zoomed into weeks.

 !screenshot-1.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: Highlight Year in Timeline

fields.description: I would like the option to have the calendar have lines on sprints. Like it does for releases, just focused on sprints.
fields.summary: Calendar Option -> Sprints

fields.description: Client would like to be able to remove Epics and other parent issue types that do not have specific story points added to them from the Unestimated issues field total when you hover over the bar for an Epic/parent under Progress (story points) in Advanced Roadmaps. This way, only Stories (in this instance) would appear in that count, so that they do not have to subtract parent issue types from the count.
fields.summary: Allow for the removal of Epics and other parent/planning issue types from the Unestimated issues field under Progress (story points)

fields.description: When there are multiple fixVersions with the same Release Date and one or more of them is Off track, the highlight line for that Release Date is orange, even if you have selected a fixVersion that is On track. Client would like this to be specific to fixVersion rather than the Release Date so that if an On track fixVersion is selected, the line is green for that Release Date (indicating the On track fixVersion).
fields.summary: Make Release Date Highlight fixVersion Specific in the Timeline

fields.description:
Currently for a custom date to be available, the [custom date field needs to be added to the schemes of all the projects|https://confluence.atlassian.com/adminjiraserver/project-screens-schemes-and-fields-938847220.html] associated with the issue sources of the plan. Once selected, the custom dates will be displayed with the date lozenge. 

The request is to allow custom field date to be displayed with the date lozenge if it is assigned to some of the issue types.
fields.summary: Allow Custom field date with its context to certain issue types to be selected as an End Date

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

If the task has more than one sprint assigned to it, then it's shown only in the closed sprint and not the current (open) despite this task is assigned to this sprint anyway.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create an issue and assign it to a Sprint
 # Close the Sprint and move the issue to a new Sprint
 # The issue will have two Sprint values in the Sprint field.
 # Close the issue
 # Go to the plan and verify the issue, it is listed under previous Sprint and not the current Sprint

h3. Expected Results

It should be present in the current Sprint
h3. Actual Results

It shows the previous sprint
{noformat}
...
{noformat}
h3. Workaround

N/A
fields.summary: If a resolved issue has more than 1 Sprint value it doesn’t appear inside correct Sprint on the plan

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

When viewing a Plan, you can create Issues in the Plan and then commit the changes to go ahead and create the Issues in Jira.  If you create several child Issues and then commit changes, the Child issues are created in reverse order, resulting in the child issues being shown in reverse order within the Jira issue. 
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Navigate to a Plan. 
 # Select the "Create Issue" option and create a Parent Issue.  We used the Task issue type. 
 # Once the Parent issue is created, select the meatballs (...) next to the Task name and select "Create Sub-task".
 # Create multiple Sub-tasks in a specific order (ie- Sub-task 1, Sub-task 2, Sub-Task 3). 
 # Review Changes and Commit changes.  This will generate the Issue keys for these Issues.  
 # The Issue keys are created in reverse order.  For example, if the Project key is ARJ, then the Parent Task would be ARJ-1 and Sub-task 3 would be ARJ-2, Sub-task 2 would be ARJ-3 and Sub-task 1 would be ARJ-4.
 # Click on the Parent Task to open the Issue in full-screen.  The Sub-tasks are displayed in reverse order.  

h3. Expected Results

The Sub-tasks will be assigned Issue keys in the order that they were created. 
h3. Actual Results

The Sub-tasks are assigned Issue keys in the reverse order that they were created. 
h3. Workaround

Currently there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: Bulk Sub-task creation through Plan creates issues in reverse order

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

In plans, it is possible to set the number of days after which 'completed issues' will not be displayed in the view.

A program displays an aggregated data of multiple plans. Since the 'completed issues' setting is not available in Programs, it should be inherited from the used plans. However, the program view doesn't follow the same configuration as in the plans and this setting seems to be hardcoded to 30 days.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create a plan
 # Under _Plan Configuration > Issue Sources_, set the 'Completed issues' to 1 day.
 # Create a program based on the plan created in step 2. 
 # Create an Epic and create two stories under that Epic. Resolve one story.
 # In the plan, you can see the Epic with both stories:
 !PlanView.png|width=693,height=315!
 # In the program, you can see the Epic showing the 'status breakdown' with both issues (one is resolved and one is open)
 !ProgramView.png|width=693,height=314!
 # *After one day*, the resolved issue will disappear from the plan view ('Completed issues' et to 1 day).
 !Plan-1d.png|width=766,height=248!
 # However, the 'status breakdown' in the program view still shows both issues.
 !Program1d.png|width=745,height=371!

h3. Expected Results

The status breakdown in programs should follow the 'Completed issues' setting in Plans.
h3. Actual Results

Resolved issues are removed from the status breakdown in program view after 30 days.
h3. Workaround

Currently, there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available

*Note:*
 * This is especially confusing when 'Completed Issues' in plan is set to more than 30 days. Resolved issues will be displayed in plans but not in the program.
 * As a way to fix this, we can inherit the max value from the plans or add a 'Completed Issues' setting to the programs.
fields.summary: Status breakdown in programs doesn't match 'Completed Issues' setting in plans

fields.description:
What we are looking for is the ability to select throughput as a scheduling calculation when setting up a team (in tandem with being able to set the Sprint length)
How we envision it working is you would set your individual teams throughput (similar to how you would currently set a teams velocity). The calculations would then count each Story level ticket as one point against that throughput.
For example:
 - Team A has a throughput of 5 for a 2 week Sprint
 - Epic 1 has 10 Story level items assigned to it
 - It would take Team A 2 Sprints (4 weeks) to complete Epic 1
fields.summary: Ability to use throughput calculations rather than story point or time based estimates on Advanced Roadmaps

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
Our Advanced Roadmap documentation for the REST API at https://docs.atlassian.com/portfolio-for-jira-server/REST/2.13.0/jpo/ does not state that it will return up to 100 plans.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create more than 100 live plans on Advanced Roadmap
# Run the  http://<jira base url>/rest/jpo-api/1.0/plan

h3. Expected Results
JSON with all the plans

h3. Actual Results
JSON with 100 plans

h3. Workaround
* Get how many plans exist
http://<jira base url>/rest/jpo-api/1.0/plan/count
* It will return the total number of plans, for instance, 108
* Doing a small calc (108/100), we will see that we will need 2 pages to get all the results:
 http://<jira base url>/rest/jpo-api/1.0/plan?page=1
 http://<jira base url>/rest/jpo-api/1.0/plan?page=2
fields.summary: REST API doc should mention that it does return up to 100 plans

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

Currently, Advanced Roadmap displays the progress bar in the scheduling view based on the Target Start and Target End field values. Here's how it look like now:

 !Current.png|thumbnail! 

It's common for users to change the "end" date due to numerous factors. Some users in Jira also utilize "Due Date" field to specify when they would like an issue to be completed. In some cases where due date is different than target end date, some users would like to be able to view this information directly in the scheduling view so they can adjust the target end date.

h3. Suggested Solution

Allow users to view due date in scheduling view like what's shown in the following screenshot:

 !Expected.png|thumbnail! 

h3. Workaround 

None
fields.summary: Allow users to view due date in scheduling view

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

if a user updates the view in a Roadmap plan, save the view and then the user gets deactivated, Roadmap hides the user's detail in the "Saved views" page rather than showing the user as an inactive user.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 
# Create a Roadmap plan
# Change the view on the plan (Eg: add a field)
# Save the view (Click on 3 dots beside "Views" -> Save)
# Click on "Views" -> "Manage Views"
# Check the "Last updated" entry and the full name and username of the user who changed the view will be shown.
# Login to Jira as an Administrator user.
# Disable the user.
# Access the plan used to reproduce the problem and navigate to the "Saved views" page.
# Full name and username of the user who made changed to the plan's view will be hidden.

Screen recording of the steps:  [^JPOSERVER-3079.webm] 

h3. Expected Results

Plan shows the full name and username of the user who was disabled with the "Inactive" entry to indicate that the user is disabled.

h3. Actual Results

Full name and username of the user will be hidden on the "Saved views" page.

 !Screenshot 2021-10-18 at 3.13.15 PM.png|thumbnail! 

h3. Workaround

None
fields.summary: Advanced Roadmap hides user in "Saved views" when user is deactivated.

fields.description:
[The rest API documentation|https://docs.atlassian.com/portfolio-for-jira-server/REST/3.29.0/jpo/] includes an endpoint to delete plans, however, this method has not been implemented yet and there is a suggestion ticket for it:
 * JPOSERVER-2674: Implement the REST API endpoint to delete plans
fields.summary: Documentation - Delete Plan endpoint not available

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

If users accessed the following endpoint:

* <Jira URL>/rest/jpo-api/1.0/plan

Jira will provide following response which shows * planTeams* ID:

{code}
"nonWorkingDays": [],
"planTeams": [
6,
8,
9,
7,
5,
10,
2,
1
],
"excludedVersions": [],
"title": "Test Plan",
"planningUnit": 0,
"portfolioPlanVersion": 1,
"id": 1
}
{code}

The ID does not the correct value corresponding to the Team in Roadmap but rather ID in *AO_D9132D_PLANTEAM* table. Using this REST endpoint, customers are unable to find the teams which has been added to the plan.

+Steps to repoduce+

# Add shared team to plan and commit the changes.
# Access /rest/jpo-api/1.0/plan endpoint and check the planTeams value.
# Remove a shared team, commit the changes and add same team again
# Access /rest/jpo-api/1.0/plan endpoint again and we will see that planTeams value added to the same team which was re-added to the plan. 

h3. Suggested Solution

Allow /rest/jpo-api/1.0/plan endpoint to retrieve Team ID in response.

h3. Workaround 

None.
fields.summary: Display Team ID with plan rest endpoint

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

As Advanced Roadmaps for Jira's plan view currently does not support multiple values in the *Releases* column, if you create an issue (Issue-1) that is associated with two different releases: *Release A* and *Release B*, if you introduce a filter to return issues associated with *Release B*, Advanced Roadmaps may return *Issue-1* while displaying *Release A* under the *Releases* column which is confusing to users.
 
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create a plan.
 # Create two issues: *Issue-1* and *Issue-2*
 # Associate *Issue-1* with the *Release A* and *Release B* fix version/s in Jira Software.
 # Associate *Issue-2* with the *Release B* fix version in Jira Software.
 # Ensure that *Release A's id* is the first value returned by the backlog request.

h3. Expected Results
* As we are filtering for *Release B*, we would expect all issues to display *Release B* under the *Releases* column.

h3. Actual Results
* Issue-1 will display *Release A* under the *Releases* column.

 !Screen Shot 2021-10-13 at 11.25.57.png|thumbnail! 

h3. Workaround

 Currently, there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: Plan filters display issues with different Release values under that column

fields.description:
Currently, even though a Jira Software issue can have multiple values for the *Fix Version/s* field, Advanced Roadmaps only supports a single value in the *Releases* field and it can cause issues as the plan view will automatically select the first id returned by the backlog request.

It would be an improvement if Advanced Roadmaps for Jira supported multiple values for the release field and allowed users to order these values as they please as well.
fields.summary: Support multiple values for the Release field in plan view

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

Currently, all issues in a Roadmap plan are required to use the same Priority scheme to allow users to order issues in the plan based on "priority" option. If issues in the plan use different priority schemes, users will unable to sort issues based on priority and the following message will be shown:

{quote}
To sort issues by priorities, the projects in the plan must be using the same priority scheme.
{quote}


h3. Suggested Solution

Add support for Roadmap to allow plan to work with more than 1 priority scheme. Jira has   record of all the priorities in the "Priorities" page where it can be used as a fallback mechanism to sort issues based on priority:

 !Screenshot 2021-10-12 at 11.33.58 AM.png|thumbnail! 


h3. Workaround 

None.
fields.summary: Allow Roadmap plan to work with multiple Priority Scheme

fields.description:

fields.description:
Currently, Advanced Roadmaps only allow the selection of *Labels* that already exist in Jira Software. 

It would certainly increase the value provided by the application if users were able to insert a new value for that field and have the ability to commit this new value back to Jira Software.
fields.summary: Allow Advanced Roadmaps to create new labels and commit them back to Jira Software

fields.description: we would like the ability to edit Team Member's capacity in Advanced Roadmaps, that way we can fit distribute the issues to team members with different levels of skill sets, this would help to improve the way our customers handle issues distribution in the Advanced Roadmaps
fields.summary: ability to edit Team Member's capacity in Advanced Roadmaps

fields.description: Jira is an fantastic planning tool.  With steps now into GANTT charts for extended planning across teams this open up a world of possibilities.  Our business relies on some physical components - sensors, hardware, and supply chain are all external inputs to the plans on when a product and software + hardware capability can be deployed.  So, the next question I have is - how can we integrate supply chain dates, times and resource tracking into Jira Advanced Roadmaps ?  We have physical sensors being produced overseas, there is the manufactured, the thousands of components that go into the sensor, as well as assembly and shipping times that all need to be tracked - in conjunction with the software which is deployed on these manufactured sensors.  This seems like an area ripe for exploring Advanced Roadmaps.
fields.summary: Enterprise Reporting

fields.description:
We use Jira project categories to aggregate issues and goals (Epics) per management field. It would therefore be very beneficial for us if the Roadmap view would include project categories in these areas:
 * Ability to group by project category (View Settings)
 * Offer project category as an option when adding fields
fields.summary: Project categories in roadmap view

fields.description:
While working with multiple items on a timeline, it would be easier to understand which issues are being manipulated if the Issue Summary could be displayed inside (or alongside) the Timeline Bar.

This would make working with larger amounts of data easier, especially if you could collapse all field columns and work directly with the Timeline Bars. As a user, especially for rough planning work, I don't want to fiddle with dates or fields, I just want to slap some bars down on the timeline and adjust as needed to fit the current constraints.
fields.summary: Display Issue Summary on Timeline Bar

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

The [Advanced Roadmaps for Jira in Confluence|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/apps/1221237/advanced-roadmaps-for-jira-in-confluence?hosting=server&tab=overview] macro added to a Confluence page fails to load a Roadmap from a Jira On-prem instance if there is a mismatch in the Application URL used in the AppLink and the URL from the Roadmap Link.

The issue only affects versions 1.2.0 and above of the app [Advanced Roadmaps for Jira in Confluence|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/apps/1221237/advanced-roadmaps-for-jira-in-confluence?hosting=server&tab=overview].
h3. Steps to Reproduce

Tested on Confluence 7.4 and 7.13 linked to a Jira 8.18 instance:
 # Install Jira 8.18.
 # Install Confluence 7.4 or 7.13.
 # Create an Application link between them using the same URL as Application URL and Display URL:
 ** In the tests performed, it was [http://localhost:8080|http://localhost:8080/]
 # Install the *Advanced Roadmaps for Jira in Confluence* app (version 1.1.0) on Confluence.
 # Add an *Advanced Roadmaps* macro to a Confluence page and link it to a valid Roadmap from Jira.
 # If the URL from the Roadmap Link and the Application URL from the AppLink match (see example below), the macro works as expected (/):
 ** Application URL from the AppLink Confluence->Jira: [http://localhost:8080/]
 ** Roadmap Link: [http://localhost:8080/secure/PortfolioRoadmapConfluence.jspa?r=1hFAg]
 # Edit the AppLink and change the Application URL to a different but valid URL such as [http://127.0.0.1:8080|http://127.0.0.1:8080/] (which points to the same location as *localhost*, in this case).
 # Check the page where the macro was added and it is still working as expected.   !https://getsupport.atlassian.com/images/icons/emoticons/check.png|width=16,height=16!
 # Update the app to version 1.2.0 or higher.
 # Check the page where the macro was added and it is no longer working as expected. (x)
 ** This is due to a mismatch in the URL from the Roadmap Link and the Application URL.
 ** Application Link Confluence->Jira, Application URL: [http://127.0.0.1:8080/]
 ** Roadmap Link: [http://localhost:8080/secure/PortfolioRoadmapConfluence.jspa?r=1hFAg]
 ** If you replace *localhost* in the Roadmap Link above with the IP address we are using on this example, the macro starts working again.

h3. Expected Results

The Roadmap would be displayed on the Confluence page.
h3. Actual Results

The message below is displayed instead:
{quote}*Error rendering macro 'portfolio-for-jira-plan'*

It looks like you've entered a URL to a Jira that is not connected to Confluence. Contact your administrator to configure an Application Link
{quote}
h3. Additional Notes

If we go back to the Release Notes for [Release Notes|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/apps/1221237/advanced-roadmaps-for-jira-in-confluence/version-history] for v1.2.0 of this app, we can see the following:
{quote}Note to administrators: This new version pulls Advanced Roadmaps data from Jira *using Application Links*. To ensure a smooth upgrade, please make sure that the Application Link between your Confluence and Jira servers is set up. If you update to the new version without this connection, your Macro might not work as intended
{quote}
We have some cases where customers set an AppLink between Confluence and Jira using different URLs for Display URL and Application URL.

This is done, for example, when setting an [unproxied application link|https://confluence.atlassian.com/kb/how-to-create-an-unproxied-application-link-719095740.html]. Usually, the Display URL will match the Base URL for the Jira instance, which is not the same URL set for the Application URL.

When generating the Roadmap Link on Jira, it will use the Base URL as a reference.

h3. Workaround

The user can use one of the following workarounds:
# Downgrade the app [Advanced Roadmaps for Jira in Confluence|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/apps/1221237/advanced-roadmaps-for-jira-in-confluence?hosting=server&tab=overview] to version 1.10, as long as you are running a Confluence version compatible with it; or
# Set the Application URL in the AppLink to be equal to the Display URL, if possible; or
# When adding the Roadmap Link to the macro on a Confluence page, manually change the URL to use the Application URL from the AppLink (see step 10 in the *Steps to Reproduce* section).
fields.summary: Advanced Roadmaps for Jira in Confluence macro fails to load if there is a mismatch in the Application URL used in the AppLink and the Roadmap Link

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Currently this is not possible to retrieve detailed information of members of a given team using a single API call. The following method would return the respective resources IDs, but that would still require another call to retrieve relevant details for the people members of a team.

{code}
GET <Jira Base URL>/rest/teams-api/1.0/resource
{code}

h3. Suggested Solution
Provide API endpoints to give Jira admins the opportunity of retrieving people details for a specified team on a single call.
fields.summary: Provide REST API methods to retrieve detailed info about team members (people)

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

Currently in the Improved Interface, when building a CPR, one must select from preexisting Releases in each Software Project that is in the Plan.  

Previously in Live Plans, one could build a CPR and then push out the Release to multiple Projects in the Plan and it would create a Release in the Project. 

Previous documentation: [Creating and configuring cross-project releases|https://confluence.atlassian.com/advancedroadmapsserver/creating-and-configuring-cross-project-releases-813891772.html]

Current documentation: [Releases in Advanced Roadmaps|https://confluence.atlassian.com/jirasoftwareserver/releases-1044784195.html] - see the Cross Project Release section.  The release will not be saved to Jira Software, it is only in ARJ. 
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Build a Plan in Advanced Roadmaps. 
 # From the *Releases* tab, select *Create release* next to the project name.
 # Name your release, add a description, and choose the *project* and *release* you want to add. Then select *Add release*.
 # Repeat to add as many releases as necessary.
 # When you’re happy with your release, select *Create* and your new release will be added to the plan.
 

Cross-project releases are only used in Advanced Roadmaps and cannot be saved to Jira Software.

h3. Expected Results

CPR releases will save to Jira Software as previously. 
h3. Actual Results

The release is only present in ARJ. 
h3. Workaround

Currently there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: Ability to save Cross Project Releases to Software Projects

fields.description:
As a Solution Manager, I would like  to be able to color issues in a "Validate" type of state to be a different color than the other "Implement" types of states.  Right now  there seems to  be 3 colors, Not in work Gray, In Work Blue, and Closed Green.  This makes it  difficult  to easily and graphically represent the progress of higher level issues.

Something as simple as the "+ Add Color" option that  is  provided when colored by Issue Type would work great.
fields.summary: Allow Custom Colors for Status coloring

fields.description:
h4. Feature request
Advanced Roadmaps for Jira (improved planning interface) renders the column for "Story points" with a fixed label. It does not reflect the actual name of the field. 

This is a problem because it can misguide users on what the actual field name is:
* The default field is "Story Points" (with a capital P), not "Story points"
* There can be many "Story Points" style fields in Jira, including perhaps "Story points" (lower P), which is not the right field
* The true source of the field is opaque -> it is not documented, and the way to change it is obscure, requiring a database change
* Story Points field can be renamed to something else (in the event of instance consolidation, migration, other arbitrary reason). 
* Boards can use multiple estimation fields, ARJ doesn't support this, rather it uses the JSW default

h4. Suggested solution
Render the name of the column as the actual field name. This self-solves and guide the customer to the problem
fields.summary: Render the "Story points" column name as the Jira field name

fields.description:
Hi,

We have created a Confluence space for us to collaborate with one of our customers on a project. Within this space, we have created a page and linked a roadmap we created for the customer to this (from Advanced Roadmap > Share plan as > Confluence).

However, when the customer is viewing the page they cannot see the roadmap. They instead see an embedded webpage (I think this is our service desk/support page). 

I added the customer's group to the Advanced roadmap permission, but this still didn't work. Only after I added the customer's group to Jira access did it work. However, this is not suitable as:
A) none of the issues are pulling through to the roadmap as they don't have access to the project (and we don't want to give this view access to the whole of this project)
B) the customer can see project names etc. which we don't want them to
C) we would incur additional costs to add them as a Jira user. 

I also tried the iframe method, but the result was the same. 

I would've assumed that the roadmap would be viewable for everyone that has access to the space, but this is not the case. How can I allow the customer (or internal support teams that don't have access to Jira) to view this?

Thanks, 

Damien
fields.summary: Viewability on Confluence

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

When there are two fields in Jira named “Team”, one custom, the other from ARJ, the UI will only display a single entry when trying to add this field into Plan view, when added, it will show both the custom field and the ARJ field and it's not possible to have only a single one appearing.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a custom field named *Team*
!image-2021-09-02-10-43-07-887.png|thumbnail! 
# Allow the custom field to be used in ARJ Plan:
!image-2021-09-02-10-44-43-376.png|thumbnail! 
# On ARJ Plan, try to add +one+ of the *Team* fields, only a single option will be shown:
 !image-2021-09-02-10-45-15-919.png|thumbnail! 
# When adding this single entry, both fields will be displayed:
!image-2021-09-02-10-51-00-594.png|thumbnail! 
# When removing the single entry available, both columns are removed

h3. Expected Results
Both fields are identified and can be added/removed separately

h3. Actual Results
Only one of the fields is available at the picker and will result on both fields being added/removed from plan view

h3. Workaround
One alternative, is to "rename" the custom field in Jira through the usage of the *translation feature*, which should not break any references in JQLs/Filters to your current Team field in Jira, as described on [Translating Custom Fields|https://confluence.atlassian.com/adminjiraserver/translating-custom-fields-1047552721.html], using the current instance language

By performing this method, you should be able to change the way the custom field name is presented, as to identify it as being from Jira, such as TeamsJira or similar, which would allow it to be separated from it's ARJ counterpart.

With this we are able to successfully list two *Team* fields, as my custom one is being translated into *jTeam* and referenced as such by ARJ:

 !screenshot-1.png|thumbnail! 
 !screenshot-2.png|thumbnail! 
 !screenshot-3.png|thumbnail! 

While in Jira on display it will use the name *jTeam*, but for any filtering purposes it retains it's original name:

 !screenshot-4.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: Advanced Roadmaps does not allow to pick one "Team" field to display in plan

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

Currently, when dependencies cannot be added to the roadmap plan between issues, we only see an error that says, "Something went wrong", which does not provide us any information
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Try to add dependency
 # Error appears as "something went wrong"

h3. Expected Results

Give a valid error message stating that the dependency configuration is not setup as expected or something relevant.
h3. Actual Results

!image-2021-09-02-13-01-05-674.png|width=883,height=123!
h3. Workaround

Currently there is no known workaround for this behavior.
fields.summary: Invalid error messages thrown in advanced roadmap

fields.description:
As an advanced roadmap user I want to be able to easily exclude labels or components from a filter search so that I can narrow down my search results.

 

*Use case:*

Using labels as an example, but use case is true with other fields like components. We have many different labels tied to our issues. Sometimes, we would rather just exclude a certain label from the list, but that requires us to select all other labels first. The label filter doesn't have a 'select all' checkbox like status has. A select all box would allow for us to easily select all labels, then find the label we want to exclude.
fields.summary: Exclude labels and components in Advanced Roadmap

fields.description:
We would like to have the possibility to include a Multi-user picker in Advanced Roadmaps, right now, this type of custom field is not supported.

*Use case:*
 We use a project called 'ABC' which is basically an ideation board (where all issue types are epics), from there we link development stories from other dev projects (mobile app, web, backend) to those epics. Our ideation board includes stakeholders, brand digital teams, and our design team in addition to product management. As we plan at the 'ABC' level, we assign product managers to those. We had a custom single user picker field for this, but we soon realized that for features that go across products (app and backend), we wanted to capture the two product managers in that field.
fields.summary: Multi-user picker in Advanced Roadmaps

fields.description: In the [Configure your Jira Software instance|https://confluence.atlassian.com/jirasoftwareserver/configure-your-jira-software-instance-1044784156.html] page, the menu *!https://confluence.atlassian.com/jirasoftwareserver/files/951394823/951394824/1/1527598725017/cog_icon.png|width=18! > Products* under section "_3. Add custom hierarchy levels to your Advanced Roadmaps plan:_" is incorrect. It should be *!https://confluence.atlassian.com/jirasoftwareserver/files/951394823/951394824/1/1527598725017/cog_icon.png|width=18! > Manage apps* instead for Jira Server and Data Center.
fields.summary: Correct Advanced Roadmap menu for Jira Server and Data Center

fields.description:
The Parent Link field (Portfolio for Jira) currently allows users to select issues that are closed. I cannot imagine a use case where this would make sense.

As far as I know the Epic Link field doesn't allow closed Epics to be selected. And I suggest to make the Parent Link field behave in that way as well.
fields.summary: Parent Link field shouldn't allow users to select closed issues

fields.description:
Currently, When a sprint is assigned, the capacity is only calculated for that specific sprint. At the moment there's no direct association between moving an issue manually on the timeline and assigning a sprint. 

It will be great to have this feature implemented in advanced roadmap so that we can simply review the change after planning it, because at the moment, we will have to change the value and change the sprint in Jira separately after planning which is tedious.
fields.summary: Capacity indicator should change for planned sprints and update them in Jira

fields.description: Currently, it is not possible to synchronize from advanced roadmap plan to Jira fields without reviewing the changes. It would be great to have an ability to toggle between manual review and auto review. When switched to automatically review, the changes would be updated to the Jira without reviewing change.
fields.summary: Ability to toggle review option in advanced roadmap

fields.description:
Currently the following are not possible in Roadmaps:
 # See the reporter of a ticket
 # Filter tickets by reporter
 # Colour tickets by reporters
fields.summary: Can't see reporter, group by and filter by reporter

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

When creating an issue through an Advanced Roadmaps plan and assigning it to a specific user it works as expected, but after *Reviewing the changes*, the Issue’s assignee changes to the Project Lead.
h3. Steps to Reproduce

!Screen Recording 2021-08-10 at 14.13.33.gif|width=891,height=452!
h3. Expected Results

The issue keeps the Assignee that was manually set
h3. Actual Results

The Assignee is being changed to the Project Lead
h3. Workaround

Currently, there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available.
fields.summary: Assignee being replaced by Project Lead when creating Issue trough an Advanced RoadmapsPlan

fields.description:
Currently we have *Estimates (h) column* that shows the *remaining hours* and we also have the *hover* that shows Total, Completed and Remaining as we can see on this [link|https://confluence.atlassian.com/advancedroadmapscloud/monitor-estimates-and-issues-998651043.html]

Would be very important to have two new columns: 
 * *Logged*: The total hours logged on time tracking / work log
 * *Estimated*: The total estimated hours on time tracking

The existing *Estimates (h)* *column* should actually be renamed to *Remaining (h)* in order to avoid confusion, as we know the *Estimates (h) column* does not show estimated but remaining.

Here is my question [ticket|https://community.atlassian.com/t5/Advanced-Roadmaps-questions/How-to-add-estimated-and-or-logged-columns-to-roadmap/qaq-p/1767362] that brought me here.
fields.summary: Add Estimated and Logged columns to Advanced Roadmap

fields.description:
As a user of AR, I would like for Roll-Up Dates displayed on a Plan to also be reflected in a Program that includes the Plan.

 

The new Roll-up Dates feature for Plans is great!  That said, it loses the efficiencies gained when trying to visualize multiple plans with a program.  Since the Roll-Up dates don't record back to the Jira issue, a Program shows nothing for the Initiatives/Capabilities/Epics without manual entry of the Target Start/End in each Plan.
fields.summary: Reflect Plan Roll-up Dates on Program

fields.description:
h3. Suggestion

As a user, I would like to see details of an Issue when clicked.

Currently when an issue in the plan is clicked, the Issue loads in a pop-up new window/tab. 

However, it would be more streamlined to have something similar to Jira Software's _Issue Detail_ view on the board:

!image-2021-08-02-16-57-16-501.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: As a user, I would like to see details of an Issue when hovered or clicked.

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
Missing issues from Advanced Roadmap plan when issues tied to their releases were moved across projects

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create Issue A on Project 1, create a release in Project 1
# Create Issue B on Project 2, create a release in Project 2
# Create Advanced Roadmap Plan X with both projects as issue source
# Auto-schedule Plan X so that both issues are assigned to their respective releases
# Move Issue B to Project 1
# Remove Project 2 from issue source of Plan X
# Observe that Issue B is no longer shown in the plan

h3. Expected Results
Both issues A and B are included in Plan X

h3. Actual Results
Issue B is missing from Plan X

h3. Workaround
Auto-schedule plan to force a recalculation to redisplay both issues in the plan. 

h3. Notes
This is happening because data related to the moved issues like PROJECT, VERSION, etc are still referring to their original project in {{AO_D9132D_ASSIGNMENT_EXT}} table. Hence, the issues were excluded from the plan until a new recalculation refreshes the data and takes them into considerations.
fields.summary: Missing issues from Advanced Roadmap plan when issues tied to their releases were moved across projects

fields.description: Currently, in Advanced Roadmaps, the *Parent Link* field only supports a single value. However, under certain circumstances, Jira Administrators might need to link a child issue (Epic) to multiple parents (Initiatives).
fields.summary: Ability to add multiple values to the Parent Link field
